title: What are the elements in Group 3 on the periodic table? - Quora

response.answer_text: The four group 3 elements are scandium, yttrium, lanthanum and actinium. “lanthanide” refers to the elements between lanthanum and lutetium. That term does not encompass scandium and yttrium. Scandium and yttrium act pretty much identically to lanthanides. I've worked and published extensively with both as well as various lanthanides*. I could call myself a “lanthanide chemist” but I prefer the more accurate term “rare earth chemist”. This phrase includes the first three group 3 elements as well. Group three metals are not transition metals. They are in the d block but they basically do not exhibit multiple oxidation states. They are sometimes classed as “main group” because they have superficially similar chemistry to alkaline earth metals, except they are 3+ rather than 2+ in the latter.they are sometimes referred to as “f block” because of the essentially identical reactivity to the lanthanides, but this is also inaccurate as they do not have an f electrons in their atomic confifuration. The most accurate description is “rare earth”. Because they don't change oxidation state, most of their reactions go by sigma bond metathesis routes, a lovely and simple mechanism to draw! Like the lanthanides it is their size, rather than their electronic configuration that distinguishes them chemically. I.e. if you want to do rare earth catalysis you will probably screen for a range of them because they will likely have similar reactivities but have different rates. Sometimes you can slightly tweak your metal centre and reactions that did not go before are suddenly very facile.** Sm and Ce are more willing to change oxidation state so they can react differently. I hope this helps! * Ive used them all except Pm, Tb and Tm at some point, as well as 6 months dabbling in uranium chemistry. ** see Scandium-catalysed intermolecular hydroaminoalkylation of olefins with aliphatic tertiary amines. This is my selective screening table for this reaction from this paper: you'll see that whilst certain Sc species catalyse the reaction, the equivalent Y, Lu, Gd and Sm did not. I'm sure I tried others as well but the results were probably not clear enough to publish.
